title: Individual corpora

author: Ann Copestake, Computer Laboratory, University of Cambridge

segmentation: We want to, to some extent, follow on from what we've just been talking about.
But I want to suggest that there are there is something that I really, really think we ought to do, which will actually cost a fair amount of money and is to do with corpora.
And it's this idea of having corpora, which are individual weighted, so that we know what an individual speaker hears and says.

As opposed to these very, very large huge text corpora we have, which are these is this huge shmoos of information from all over the place where we very rarely get to know what an individual person was saying or hearing.
And there's some absolutely basic things that we don't know because we don't have this resource.
There is no good estimate for how many words an average individual speaks and writes in a day.
You can see all sorts of numbers on the web.
They appear to have been made up with really no information.
You'll see all sorts of things like women save more than men.
We don't know whether it's true or not.
Probably is rubbish, but we don't know.
We don't know how many words an individual hears and reads each day.
We don't know whether it's you know, 50 thousands or.
Yeah, 100,000 we don't know the variation.
We don't know how that might vary depending on your age.
We don't know.
We don't know how much of our speech and language production is in different modalities.
We don't know how much people are talking on mobiles.
We don't know how much you're typing an email or Facebook and so on.
There's all sorts of very, very basic things we don't know because we don't track an individual's language use.
We don't know things about language used by, by and trilingual speakers.
Typically you're going to switch between languages.
We don't know how people do that.
Don't know much about variation between speakers.
We don't know about vocabulary effects of previous discourse.
I mean, we know in theory that if somebody starts using a word, then the other person will will pick it up and you know, use it.
But we don't really know how often that happens.
We don't know about variation according to the modality with which you're an individual speaking.
We don't know very much about register differences.
We crucially don't know about negotiation of meaning between speakers.
When we get a very, very large text corpus we have.
We have words from every speaker with every possible use, but that's not actually.
Realistic in terms of what an individual understands by a meaning of a word.
I believe so if we actually.
I'm going to sort of do serious scientific investigation of this.

I think that in order to use distributional semantics properly, I would really, really like a corpus that was adjusted for individual use.
